heroSection.title: You've got this!
heroSection.description:
Stepping back into the world of education might seem daunting, but remember, every great journey begins with a single step—and you're already on your way. This plan isn't just a guide; it's a reflection of your ambition, your dreams, and your future.

Here's what you're unlocking:

  • Clarity and Confidence: No more second-guessing. Every piece of advice here is tailored to help you navigate your educational journey with ease.
  • A Future Tailored to You: Your goals, your aspirations, your pace. Embrace the exciting opportunities that lie ahead.

You've got the ambition and the drive. With this plan in hand, you're not just going back to school; you're moving forward in life. Let's dive in and advance your future together.

reasons.title: Is Earning My Bachelor’s Degree Really Worth It?

image.altText: Graduate celebrating wearing a cap and gown

accordionList.title: Higher Earning Potential
accordionList.description: On average, bachelor's degree holders earn significantly more over their lifetime than those with only a high school diploma. Investing in your education can pave the way for a higher salary and improved financial stability.

accordionList.title: Broader Career Opportunities
accordionList.description: Many positions, especially in growing industries like technology, healthcare, and finance, often require or prefer candidates with a bachelor's degree. By completing your degree, you unlock a wider range of job prospects.

accordionList.title: Personal Growth & Development
accordionList.description: Beyond the career implications, college offers a holistic experience. You'll be exposed to diverse perspectives, subjects, and opportunities for personal and intellectual growth. This enriching environment can enhance your worldview, critical thinking skills, and interpersonal dynamics.

accordionList.title: Networking Opportunities
accordionList.description: College isn't just about what you learn in the classroom. It's also about the connections you make. Alumni networks, professors, peers, internships, and campus organizations can all provide valuable connections that might benefit your future career.

accordionList.title: Flexibility & Adaptability
accordionList.description: As industries evolve, those with a higher level of education tend to have an easier time adapting to changes in the job market. A bachelor's degree equips you with transferable skills that are valuable in a variety of roles.

statsSource: Association of Public and Land Grant Universities

stats.title: Higher Salary
stats.description: Typical earnings for bachelor’s degree holders are 84% higher than those whose highest degree is a high school diploma.

stats.title: More Lifetime Earnings
stats.description: College graduates on average make $1.2 million more over their lifetime.

stats.title: Less Likely to Be Unemployed
stats.description: College graduates are half as likely to be unemployed as their peers who only have a high school degree.

testimonial.text:
Something like 25 percent of entry-level jobs will be automated in the next 25 years, and so it’s likely many jobs that don’t require a bachelor’s will be eclipsed by AI or technological automation.

A college degree gives you a broad set of experiences and skills, and if or when you are replaced by a robot, or your position is diminished by new technology, with a degree you will be more nimble and better able to find another position compared to someone who hasn’t developed those skills and earned a bachelor’s degree.
testimonial.author: Ben Cater, Ph.D.
testimonial.authorTitle: Associate Dean of General Education, Point Loma Nazarene University

fundingYourDegree.title: Resources to Fund Your Education
fundingYourDegree.description: Can this automatically have the tab selected related to “Which of the following funding opportunities would you be most interested in learning about?”

tabsList.title: Scholarships
tabsList.content: Scholarships are financial awards given to students based on merit, need, or specific criteria set by the provider. They don't need to be repaid.

tabsList.title: Federal Aid
tabsList.content: The U.S. Department of Education offers various financial aid options, including grants (which don't need to be repaid) and low-interest loans.

tabsList.title: Tuiton Reimbursement
tabsList.content: Check the Employee Handbook: Many companies outline their benefits, including tuition reimbursement, in the employee handbook or benefits guide.

tabsList.title: Work Study
tabsList.content: Work-study is a federal program that provides part-time jobs to students, allowing them to earn money to help pay for school. After you enroll, your college's financial aid office can provide specifics on work-study opportunities.

tabsList.title: Military
tabsList.content: Veterans Affairs education benefits help Veterans, service members, and their qualified family members with needs like paying college tuition, finding the right school or training program, and getting career counseling.

tabsList.title: Loans
tabsList.content: Loans are borrowed funds that must be repaid with interest. They can be federal or private.

fileFafsa.title: Your First Step to Funding Your Degree: File the FAFSA
fileFafsa.description: The Free Application for Federal Student Aid (FAFSA) is the gateway to a multitude of financial aid options. By completing it, you become eligible for federal grants, work-study programs, and loans. Plus, many states and colleges use FAFSA data to award their own financial aid.

accordionList.title: It Unlocks Financial Aid Opportunities
accordionList.description: The FAFSA is the gateway to a multitude of financial aid options. By completing it, you become eligible for federal grants, work-study programs, and loans. Plus, many states and colleges use FAFSA data to award their own financial aid.

accordionList.title: It’s Not Just for Freshmen
accordionList.description: Regardless of whether you're a returning adult student or a first-time undergraduate, the FAFSA is for everyone. Age isn't a barrier; the opportunities it brings are applicable to all.

accordionList.title: It’s Not Just for Federal Aid
accordionList.description: Beyond federal aid, the FAFSA can also connect you with state-specific grants and scholarships tailored for adults returning to the educational fold. Many institutions also require the FAFSA for their own scholarship and grant opportunities.

accordionList.title: It Helps You Plan
accordionList.description: Filling out the FAFSA provides you with a clearer picture of what financial assistance you qualify for. This can be instrumental in planning your educational journey without the stress of unforeseen costs.

accordionList.title: It Matters When You File
accordionList.description: The FAFSA becomes available on October 1st each year, and deadlines can vary by state and college. It's often said,'The early bird catches the worm,' and this holds true here. The sooner you file, the better your chances of receiving the maximum amount of aid available.

stats.title: In Scholarships
stats.description: Appily’s Scholarship search tool is the nation’s largest, multi-billion dollar scholarship database. After you create a free account, you can narrow down your options and apply to any scholarships that interest you within the tool.

stats.title: Receive Aid
stats.description: Approximately 85% of full-time undergraduate students who file the FAFSA receive some kind of financial aid, according to the National Center for Education Statistics (NCES).

stats.title: Of Employers Offer Educational Benefits
stats.description: The Society for Human Resource Management (SHRM) reports that while it varies from year to year, on average, between 45-55% of employers offer tuition assistance.

moreWays.title: Transfer as many credits as you can.
moreWays.description:
Many colleges accept credits from any previous college experience you have, up to a certain amount of hours. You could also pursue alternative ways of applying credits, such as:

  • ACE: If you participated in military service, workplace training programs, apprenticeships, standardized exams, or other types of experiential learning outside the college classroom, you could receive college credit recommendations or validated competencies through Learning Evaluation.
  • CLEP: These exams let you test out of introductory courses and move to more advanced courses sooner, saving time toward your degree.

Many colleges also offer their own testing programs that allow you the opportunity to test out of introductory-level courses.

moreWays.title: Look for accelerated programs.
moreWays.description: Since colleges often charge by credit hour, look for ones that offer programs with fewer total credits needed to complete your degree.

moreWays.title: Take classes one at a time.
moreWays.description: Some degrees have asynchronous options where you can take one class at a time and complete your week’s work whenever it fits your schedule. This may make it easier to pay as you go — and fit it into your busy life.

cardsList.title: Appily’s Scholarship Database
cardsList.description: The nation’s largest, multi-billion dollar scholarship database can help you discover funding opportunities that you don’t have to pay back.

cardsList.title: ACE Credit for Prior Learning

cardsList.description: CLEP exams let you test out of introductory courses and move to more advanced courses sooner, saving time toward your degree.

careersPaths.title: How Can Your Life Experience Shape Your Career Options?

tabsList.title: Military
tabsList.content: The discipline, leadership, and strategic skills honed during military service can open doors in sectors like defense contracting, government roles, or security management. Your experience can also be highly valued in project management and logistics, where your abilities to lead and coordinate are crucial.

tabsList.title: Service Industry
tabsList.content: Your service industry experience, with its emphasis on customer relations and operational efficiency, can translate into careers in hospitality management, customer service leadership, or human resources, where your people-centric skills will continue to shine.

tabsList.title: Retail
tabsList.content: A background in retail, rich in customer service and sales experience, can pivot you toward careers in marketing, retail management, or even entrepreneurial ventures. The adaptability and commercial awareness you've gained are assets in any client-facing or business development role.

tabsList.title: Health Care
tabsList.content: Health care experience is invaluable, opening pathways to advanced clinical roles, healthcare administration, or public health advocacy. Your firsthand understanding of patient care and healthcare systems makes you a strong candidate for positions aiming to enhance healthcare delivery and policy.

tabsList.title: Self-Employed
tabsList.content: Your entrepreneurial background can propel you into leadership roles, consultancy, or business development. The initiative and innovation that come with being self-employed are sought after in the rapidly changing business landscape, tech startups, and creative industries.

tabsList.title: Parent
tabsList.content: The organizational and nurturing skills you've honed can lead to fulfilling careers in education, child development, or community services. Your talent for managing and nurturing growth is also an asset in administrative or project coordination roles.

tabsList.title: Other
tabsList.content: Diverse life experiences provide a unique lens through which you view challenges and opportunities, making you suitable for a variety of roles. Your adaptability and breadth of knowledge can be particularly advantageous in roles that require empathy, problem-solving, and a multidisciplinary approach.

topCareers.title: Top Careers in Business
topCareers.description: In the dynamic world of business, versatility and strategic acumen are paramount. The careers we've selected not only promise ample opportunities for advancement but also offer the potential for impactful roles in a variety of industries, ensuring that your investment in a business-related bachelor's degree yields substantial professional and financial rewards.

paths.title: Business Analyst
paths.description:
Job responsibilities: Analyzes organizational processes, identifies inefficiencies, and recommends solutions.

Why pursue this career: A smart choice due to the growing reliance on data-driven decision-making in business.

Related degrees: Bachelor of Business Administration (BBA) or Bachelor's in Finance

paths.title: Marketing Manager
paths.description:
Job responsibilities: Develops and oversees marketing strategies to promote products and services.

Why pursue this career: A sound career due to the constant need for businesses to differentiate and compete.

Related degrees: Bachelor's in Marketing or Bachelor's in Business Administration

paths.title: Financial Analyst
paths.description:
Job responsibilities: Evaluates investment opportunities and provides guidance to businesses or individuals.

Why pursue this career: A wise choice given the critical role of financial planning in both corporate and personal finance.

Related degrees: Bachelor's in Finance or Bachelor's in Economics

paths.title: Human Resources Manager
paths.description:
Job responsibilities: Oversees employee relations, recruitment, and compliance with labor laws.

Why pursue this career: A stable choice because of the enduring necessity of managing an organization's workforce.

Related degrees: Bachelor's in Human Resources or Bachelor's in Business Administration

paths.title: Supply Chain Manager
paths.description:
Job responsibilities: Manages the entire lifecycle of a product, from sourcing to delivery.

Why pursue this career: A prudent choice given the increasing complexity and globalization of supply chains.

Related degrees: Bachelor's in Supply Chain Management or Bachelor's in Business Administration

degreeGoals.title: How a Bachelor’s Degree Can Help You Reach Your Goals

tabsList.title: Advance Your Career
tabsList.content:
Earning a bachelor's degree can be a game-changer for career progression. Many managerial and specialized positions list a bachelor's as a minimum requirement. By broadening your knowledge base and honing key skills, you'll be positioning yourself for promotions, increased salary potential, and greater job responsibilities.

Take the Next Step: Evaluate which degrees are most respected in your profession and begin researching programs that offer flexibility around your current job. Reach out to HR to understand potential career paths and how further education can accelerate your journey.

tabsList.title: Switch Your Career
tabsList.content:
Thinking of a career shift? A bachelor's degree can provide the foundation you need to transition seamlessly. It not only equips you with new knowledge and skills but also demonstrates to potential employers your commitment to learning and adaptability. Plus, the networking opportunities during your studies can open doors to industries you haven't ventured into before.

Take the Next Step: Identify transferable skills and consider degree options that complement them. Talk to career counselors and network with individuals in the field to gain clarity on the best educational route to your new career.

tabsList.title: Finish Your Degree
tabsList.content:
Picking up where you left off and completing your degree is commendable. Finishing your bachelor's not only offers a sense of accomplishment but can also unlock opportunities that were just out of reach before. Plus, in many industries, having a completed degree can make a notable difference in earning potential and job opportunities.

Take the Next Step: Research how your credits may transfer at colleges or universities that have a program that interests you. Explore options like online courses or part-time schedules that accommodate your current lifestyle.

tabsList.title: Explore New Opportunities
tabsList.content:
A bachelor's degree is a passport to new territories—intellectually, culturally, and professionally. It offers a chance to explore diverse subjects and discover new areas that could translate into unexpected career opportunities.

Take the Next Step: Investigate interdisciplinary degree programs that allow for exploration while also making you marketable. Attend open houses and informational sessions at various colleges to see what sparks your interest.

tabsList.title: Self-Employed
tabsList.content: Your entrepreneurial background can propel you into leadership roles, consultancy, or business development. The initiative and innovation that come with being self-employed are sought after in the rapidly changing business landscape, tech startups, and creative industries.

tabsList.title: Transition from Military to Civilian Life
tabsList.content:
The discipline, leadership, and unique skills you've acquired in the military are invaluable. A bachelor's degree can complement these traits, helping you translate your military experience into civilian job roles. Additionally, the structured environment of academia can ease the transition, providing a supportive space to adapt while expanding your qualifications.

Take the Next Step: Assess your military experience and how it can apply to civilian jobs. Utilize resources like the GI Bill and speak with veteran affairs advisors at colleges to understand how your service can financially support your education and inform your degree choice.

tabsList.title: Pursue Your Passions
tabsList.content:
Earning a bachelor's degree opens a pathway to living a life driven by your passions. Whether you're drawn to the arts, fascinated by science, or inspired to make social changes, higher education equips you with the expertise and credentials to turn your personal interests into a fulfilling career. A bachelor's degree program offers in-depth knowledge and specialized skills, transforming your natural interests into professional expertise.

Take the Next Step: Reflect on what you love doing. Research degree programs that align with those interests and reach out to academic advisors or professionals in the field to gain insights into how your passions can translate into a viable career path.

yourNextSteps.title: Ready to Take On Your Future? Start Here!
yourNextSteps.description: Returning to school as an adult can feel overwhelming, but breaking the process down into manageable steps can help alleviate some of that anxiety. Here’s a good place to start:

accordionList.title: Write your “why.”
accordionList.description:
Reflect on your motivations for returning to school. What are your career goals? How will further education help you achieve them?

We suggest writing your “why” somewhere you can refer to later. Not only will this help you decide on the right program, it can be a source of motivation when any obstacles pop up.

accordionList.title: Write your “how.”
accordionList.description:
Consider your personal and professional responsibilities to determine what type of program (online, part-time, full-time) will fit into your life.

You don’t have to commit to a detailed schedule—and flexibility will be key—but knowing when you have pockets of time to dedicate to yourself and your studies can help you reach your goals.

We suggest including this with your “why.”

accordionList.title: Follow the Steps to Apply!
accordionList.description: When you’re ready, scroll down to your step-by-step guide for applying for college. We’ll guide you through the process!

topBarriers.title: Let’s Address Your Top Barrier for Completing Your Degree
topBarriers.description: Remember, every challenge has a solution, and institutions are increasingly tailoring their services to accommodate non-traditional students. Taking the first step might be daunting, but resources and support are available to help you navigate your journey back to education.

tabsList.title: Lack of Time
tabsList.content: Time management is crucial. Assess your daily schedule to find pockets of time that could be dedicated to studying. This might mean reorganizing or prioritizing tasks differently. Many institutions offer part-time programs or asynchronous online courses that allow you to work at your own pace.

tabsList.title: Family Commitments
tabsList.content: Open communication with family is important. Discuss your goals and how pursuing education will benefit the whole family in the long run. Look into schools with childcare facilities or family-friendly policies.

tabsList.title: Work Commitments
tabsList.content: Aligning your education with your career can be mutually beneficial. Have a candid discussion with your employer about your educational pursuits. Many employers value continuous learning and might offer flexible work arrangements. Also, leverage time management techniques to balance work and study effectively.

tabsList.title: Finances
tabsList.content: Understand that investing in your education is investing in your future. Look for financial aid options, scholarships, and payment plans that can ease the burden. Many institutions offer financial counseling to help you plan your education funding. Employer tuition reimbursement programs can also alleviate costs.

tabsList.title: Not Sure Which Career to Pursue
tabsList.content: Embarking on a new educational journey is an excellent opportunity to explore various careers. Utilize career assessment tools and counseling services to identify your strengths, interests, and the careers that align with them. Remember, it's okay to pivot or explore different paths until you find the one that resonates with you.

tabsList.title: Unsure Which Degree I Need
tabsList.content: Choosing the right degree is crucial for aligning your education with your career goals.Research careers you're interested in and the educational requirements for those roles.

tabsList.title: Other
tabsList.content: General hesitations or multiple obstacles can stem from a lack of information, fear of the unknown, or feeling overwhelmed by the prospect of change. Break down your concerns into manageable parts and address them systematically. Seek out stories of others who have successfully navigated similar challenges, and remember, educational institutions often have resources specifically designed to help non-traditional students.

stepsGuide.title: Your Step-by-Step Guide for Applying to College
stepsGuide.description: Applying to college as an adult can be a different experience than applying straight out of high school, but the core steps remain similar.

accordionList.title: Get Organized
accordionList.description:
• Create a folder on your desktop (or cloud storage like Google Drive) to keep copies of all your applications and correspondence.
  • Consider setting up a dedicated email address for your college-related communications to keep everything in one place.

accordionList.title: Research and Shortlist Schools
accordionList.description:
• Identify the schools and programs that align with your career goals and life situation. Consider factors like:
    • Accreditation
    • Program length
    • Cost
    • Support for non-traditional students
    • Flexible learning options such as online and evening classes

accordionList.title: Understand Application Requirements
accordionList.description:
• Each school will have its own set of requirements. Typically, these include:
    • An application form
    • Transcripts
    • Test scores (if applicable)
    • Letters of recommendation
    • Personal statements or essays
  • For adults who have been out of school for a while, emphasize professional experience and any recent educational pursuits.

accordionList.title: Gather Necessary Documents & Letters
accordionList.description:
• Request transcripts from high school and any post-secondary institutions you've attended. Note that some schools have an electronic transcript request system, which can expedite the process.
  • If the program requires standardized test scores (like the SAT, ACT, or GRE), and you haven’t taken them or your scores are outdated, register for the next available test date.
  • Begin drafting your personal statement or essay. Highlight your life and work experiences, your motivation for returning to school, and your long-term goals.
  • You may also need to provide letters of recommendation. Identify people who can vouch for your professional capabilities, work ethic, and potential as a student. These can be employers, colleagues, or mentors. Reach out to them early, providing information about the program you're applying to and why you feel they would be a good reference.

accordionList.title: Keep Track of Deadlines
accordionList.description:
• Create a timeline or spreadsheet with application deadlines for each school and program you're considering.
  • You may also consider adding deadlines to your calendar and set a reminder a few weeks out so you have plenty of time to apply.
  • Don’t forget about financial aid deadlines, which can differ from admission deadlines.

Note: Many schools with online or flexible programs offer multiple start dates throughout the year. You don’t necessarily need to wait for a fall semester start date (which is often in August).

accordionList.title: Complete Applications
accordionList.description:
• Fill out the application forms thoroughly. Some schools may have a simplified process for adult learners or non-traditional students.
  • Proofread all materials, or have someone else review them to catch any errors.

accordionList.title: Submit Financial Aid Applications
accordionList.description:
• Complete the Free Application for Federal Student Aid (FAFSA) to be considered for federal grants, loans, and work-study programs.
  • Apply for scholarships and other financial aid programs offered by the schools, community organizations, or industry associations.

accordionList.title: Follow Up
accordionList.description:
• After submitting your applications, check in to ensure that all materials have been received.
  • Stay engaged with the schools you’re interested in. Attend any informational webinars or virtual tours they offer.

textWithImage.content:
Spotlight: Build Your Application Timeline

Creating a well-structured application timeline is crucial for managing the college application process effectively, especially for adult learners who often juggle multiple responsibilities. Here's a sample timeline you can reference:

  • 12-18 Months Out:
    • Begin research on programs and institutions.
    • Start preparing for any required standardized tests.
  • 9-12 Months Out:
    • Take standardized tests if required.
    • Begin drafting personal statements or essays.
    • Request transcripts and letters of recommendation.
  • 6-9 Months Out:
    • Finalize your list of schools and understand their deadlines.
    • Begin scholarship and financial aid research.
  • 3-6 Months Out:
    • Complete and submit applications.
    • Apply for financial aid and scholarships.
  • 1-3 Months Out:
    • Follow up on applications and financial aid.
    • Prepare for interviews if required.
  • Post-Submission:
    • Await responses and make informed decisions based on acceptances and financial aid packages offered.

Remember, this timeline is a general guide. Adjust it based on your personal circumstances and the specific requirements of the programs you're applying to.
